Justification:
We are very lucky to have a strong and active civil society in France on open data.

The COVID-19 crisis has been a catalyst for collaboration between government and civil society. Open data made it possible for impactful tools to be built, for example ViteMaDose [https://vitemadose.covidtracker.fr/](https://vitemadose.covidtracker.fr/) that checks for available slots in vaccination centres and is based on the list of said centres, pharmacists and GPs that administer vaccines. The development of the COVID-19 dashboard on the Government website was also a coordinated effort from different actors to create impact : [https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/comment-les-administrations-ont-collabore-a-louverture-des-donnees-du-coronavirus-le-cas-francais](https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/comment-les-administrations-ont-collabore-a-louverture-des-donnees-du-coronavirus-le-cas-francais).

Within the framework of the Open Government Partnership [https://www.modernisation.gouv.fr/nos-actions/gouvernement-ouvert/ouvrir-laction-publique-construisons-ensemble-le-plan-daction-gouvernement-ouvert-2021-2023-de-la-france](https://www.modernisation.gouv.fr/nos-actions/gouvernement-ouvert/ouvrir-laction-publique-construisons-ensemble-le-plan-daction-gouvernement-ouvert-2021-2023-de-la-france), the next French Action Plan is being developed together with governmental actors such as the DITP, Etalab, and cada.fr, civil society associations such as madada.fr and ouvre-boite.org, and journalists. This action plan aims to create impact on important themes for French people : transparency of public action results, environmental issues, local public action, users at the heart of public action, citizen participation, digital inclusion, etc.

In 2022, Etalab has collaborated with Latitudes, a non-profit promoting « Tech for good », to design an « Open Data University » : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/home/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/home/). This program, that aims at teaching higher education students how to reuse open data, provides teachers with high impact open data projects for their students to work on and create impact. This year, 5 projects on high value added datasets have been designed and led to impactful reuses :

- Cycling infrastructures : Students are being asked to find out where to build cycling infrastructures to reduce cycling accidents and improve road safety [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_infrastructures-cyclables/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_infrastructures-cyclables/)
- Energy issues in France : Students are being asked to analyse and make predictions to better understand the possible impacts of the Ukrainian crisis on energy in France : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_energie/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_energie/)
- Middle school sectors : Students are being asked to design a tool to make it easier for parents to know which middle school to enroll their child in : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_carte-scolaire/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_carte-scolaire/)
- French recovery plan after the COVID-19 crisis : Students are being asked to assess the extent to which the aid distributed by the State as part of the recovery plan has had an impact on economic activity and/or ecological transition in France : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_france-relance/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_france-relance/)
- Electric vehicles : Students are being asked to find out whether the distribution of charging infrastructures on the territory correspond to a logic of population distribution and/or road traffic : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_vehicules-electriques/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_vehicules-electriques/)

Through the Accelerator of citizen initiatives [https://citoyens.transformation.gouv.fr/](https://citoyens.transformation.gouv.fr/), Etalab has collaborated with Infoclimat to create impact with weather data and make them more accessible to all : [https://www.infoclimat.fr/](https://www.infoclimat.fr/)

Question:
Is any data on the impact created by open data on governmental challenges (e.g. efficiency, effectiveness, transparency, decision-making capacity) available in your country? 

For justification:
* If yes, please specify what kind of data proves this impact and provide the URLs to this data.
Justification:
In 2022, Etalab has conducted a thorough study to measure the impact of open data in France. In this study, we carried out the methodology described in question 34 of this questionnaire : we combined quantitative and qualitative approaches by both analysing data.gouv.fr metrics and interviewing with data producers and reusers. Impactful use cases on different impact areas have been identified, reviewed and researched, among which governmental impact. Data on the impact created by open data on governmental challenges is available in this working paper (p.29-30 ; p.40) : : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/r/a61e1fcc-cd61-46bd-a6c5-af94cb9f8459](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/r/a61e1fcc-cd61-46bd-a6c5-af94cb9f8459).

The FING has also led an impact study on open data. Impact created by open data on governmental challenges is analysed here (from p.18 to p.25) : [https://fing.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Open-Data-impact-bilan-2010-2018-de-l-open-data.pdf#page=18](https://fing.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Open-Data-impact-bilan-2010-2018-de-l-open-data.pdf#page=18).
Guide to Answering: The governmental impact is hereby defined as the beneficial effect of the use of open data on three specific challenges faced by the government/public administrations: 1) Being efficient and effective in delivering public services; 2) Being transparent and accountable in their actions; 3) Improving their capacity to make decisions and policies.

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on the efficiency and effectiveness of the government (at any level) in delivering public services? 

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
One of the main rationale for opening data from the public sector is the efficiency and effectiveness it brings to the government in delivering public services. As stated in the final report of the Open Data Mission, opening data remains the best way for public administrations to share information to citizens in an efficient and fast way, allowing for better public action : [https://www.gouvernement.fr/upload/media/default/0001/01/2020_12_rapport_-_pour_une_politique_publique_de_la_donnee_-_23.12.2020_.pdf](https://www.gouvernement.fr/upload/media/default/0001/01/2020_12_rapport_-_pour_une_politique_publique_de_la_donnee_-_23.12.2020_.pdf).

Before open data by default, the circulation of data between actors was timely and costly (before the Digital Republic Bill, administrations could charge the access to data between each other). By publishing data and making it available to anyone, all actors can now access data without asking for one’s permission. Circulation of data between administrations then fosters innovation and improves the efficiency of public services : processes can be accelerated, policy evaluation and impact assessment can be more precise and public policies can be inspired and supported by open data exploitation.

Several high impact use cases illustrate the impact of open data on the efficiency and effectiveness of government in delivering public services. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : French companies and associations registry**

Many public administrations need information on French companies and associations to carry out their support missions towards them (information to verify the existence of a legal person, certify its validity, etc.). Public officials can now easily and quickly access this information thanks to all open business related datasets and the high impact tool developed by Etalab : [https://annuaire-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/](https://annuaire-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/). Annuaire des Entreprises centralises all the open data related to legal persons that appear in the administration’s data and makes this consolidated information available to all, free of charge : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/annuaire-des-entreprises/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/annuaire-des-entreprises/).

**Use case 2 : Publication of the energy performance diagnostic database**

The Energy Performance Diagnosis database ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/dpe-logements-existants-depuis-juillet-2021/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/dpe-logements-existants-depuis-juillet-2021/)) provides information on the energy performance of a dwelling or a building by evaluating its energy consumption and its impact in terms of greenhouse emissions. Data is collected on the field by diagnosticians and sent to a centralizing body : ADEME. Each year, ADEME had to carry out customised data extractions according to various local players requests. These extractions could take more than ten days per year. With the publication of the databases in open data, ADEME agents no longer need to perform this extraction and can now concentrate on exploiting the data.

**Use case 3 : Powering/building public services and make them more efficient thanks to open data**

Open data is now a key ressource to build digital public services. Examples are numerous, but we can cite a few :

- Avril ([https://avril.pole-emploi.fr/)](https://avril.pole-emploi.fr/)), that is using data from the operational directory of occupations and jobs for a service allowing people to obtain a diploma from their professional skills
- Code du travail numérique ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/code-du-travail-numerique/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/code-du-travail-numerique/)), that is using open data for a service facilitating access to labour law for companies and employees
- France Chaleur Urbaine ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/en/reuses/carte-france-chaleur-urbaine/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/en/reuses/carte-france-chaleur-urbaine/)) that is using open data for a service accelerating the connection of buildings to heating networks.

This use case is detailed here : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/comment-ladministration-utilise-les-donnees-publiques-lexemple-des-startups-detat/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/comment-ladministration-utilise-les-donnees-publiques-lexemple-des-startups-detat/)

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on transparency and accountability of public administrations?

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several high impact use cases illustrate the impact of open data on the transparency and accountability of public administrations. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Public finance data**

Open data has been used to design tools allowing for more transparency on public funds and a better appropriation of financial data by citizens, thus objectifying debates on local public policies as well as their financing.

During the « DataFin » hackathon based on data sets in open data : https://airtable.com/shrC4vYoq7F0wnDDu, several applications were built and are available [here](https://datafin.fr/) : https://datafin.fr/. Two projects based on open data were also launched through the General Interest Entrepreneurs programme ([https://eig.etalab.gouv.fr/)](https://eig.etalab.gouv.fr/)) to further maximise the impact for transparency and accountability :

- “[Contribute to the transparency of public funds committed for Olympics games in 2024](https://entrepreneur-interet-general.etalab.gouv.fr/defis/2020/datalympics.html) “
- “[Simplifying access to financial and statistical information for local authorities](https://entrepreneur-interet-general.etalab.gouv.fr/defis/2020/open-collectivites.html)”

Open data has been used to create a service allowing citizens to explore local government financial data with maps so as to understand it better : [https://data.ofgl.fr/pages/cartographie/](https://data.ofgl.fr/pages/cartographie/).

**Use case 2 : Aid to businesses allocated during the COVID-19 crisis**

In order to provide transparency and greater visibility on the aid to businesses allocated during the COVID-19 crisis, Etalab worked with the economic and financial ministries to consolidate and make available data on various types of aid ([https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/comment-les-administrations-ont-collabore-a-louverture-des-donnees-du-coronavirus-le-cas-francais)](https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/comment-les-administrations-ont-collabore-a-louverture-des-donnees-du-coronavirus-le-cas-francais)) : data relating to the solidarity fund set up in the context of the COVID-19, data on state-guaranteed loans in the context of the COVID19, data on tax deferrals granted in the context of the COVID-19. Etalab then developed a dashboard that makes it possible to consult and visualise the different types of aid granted by the state to companies, bringing great transparency on the way the Government managed the crisis : [https://aides-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/](https://aides-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/).

**Use case 3 : Transparency of high salaries in the public service**

Pursuant to law No 2019-828 of 6 August 2019, ministerial departments, local authorities with more than 80 000 inhabitants and hospitals with a budget of more than 200 million euros must publish annually the sum of the 10 highest gross salaries, specifying the number of women and the number of men involved. In order to make it easier for these administrations to publish such data, following a public consultation with producers and reusers, Etalab built a data schema that makes it easier to aggregate these documents.  [https://schema.data.gouv.fr/etalab/schema-hautes-remunerations/latest.html](https://schema.data.gouv.fr/etalab/schema-hautes-remunerations/latest.html) [https://github.com/etalab/schema-hautes-remunerations](https://github.com/etalab/schema-hautes-remunerations)

Several datasets have been published on [data.gouv.fr](http://data.gouv.fr/) and allow for greater transparency :

- [Ministère de la Culture](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/5ed720621bca55ea7d179ef6/)
- [Ville de Besançon](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/5ed778e37f511ace8ecc755a/)
- [Grand Besançon](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/5ed77a45b10ec70af273f990/)
- [Ville d’Antibes](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/les-10-remunerations-les-plus-elevees-au-sein-de-la-ville-dantibes/)
- [Département du Doubs](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/somme-des-dix-remunerations-les-plus-elevees/)

**Use case 4 : Publication of data related to public procurement**

According to French law, data on all public procurement contracts above 40 000 euros must be published in open data on the buyer’s profile.

The requirement for transparency and openness of public procurement data meets several objectives : it is likely to contribute to the prevention of and fight against corruption, to the good management of public funds, to the steering of purchasing policies and to the economic development of companies, which will be able to use this data either to better meet the needs of public purchasers or to develop new services to improve public procurement policies.

Data producers have to conform to a data schema [https://schema.data.gouv.fr/139bercy/format-commande-publique/latest.html](https://schema.data.gouv.fr/139bercy/format-commande-publique/latest.html) defined by law [https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/id/JORFTEXT000038318675/](https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/id/JORFTEXT000038318675/), in order to check the validity and the conformity of the files, and to make it easy to aggregate such data in a single dataset [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/5cd57bf68b4c4179299eb0e9/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/5cd57bf68b4c4179299eb0e9/)

Further information is available on the GitHub repo of the aggregation tool [https://github.com/139bercy/decp-rama](https://github.com/139bercy/decp-rama) and in the official documentation [https://139bercy.github.io/decp-docs/](https://139bercy.github.io/decp-docs/), both managed by the Ministry of the Economy.

**Use case 5 : France recovery plan following the COVID-19 crisis** 

In the framework of the Open Data University [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/home/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/home/), students have been asked to assess the extent to which the aid distributed by the State as part of the recovery plan has had an impact on economic activity and/or ecological transition in France : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_france-relance/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/odu/defi_france-relance/)

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on policy-making processes (i.e. are public administrations making use of the data as evidence for the problem identification and policy formulation)? 

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several high impact use cases illustrate the impact of open data on policy making processes. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Atlas Culture**

The « Atlas Culture des territoires » is a website designed as a reference resource for public data on culture in France : cultural places and offer, cultural public spending, cultural public policies, cultural companies, employment in the cultural field, etc. It has been built for cultural affairs officials, for them to better analyse the current situation and better design their territorial strategies for cultural development : [https://atlasculture.fr/](https://atlasculture.fr/).

**Use case 2 : The Barometer of results**

The Government developed the « Baromètre des résultats de l’action publique de l’Etat » (barometer of the results of the states’ public action), ([https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-actions-du-gouvernement/resultats)](https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-actions-du-gouvernement/resultats)) a tool allowing citizens and policymakers at any level to monitor the implementation of France’s main public policies. The barometer is powered by open data [available on data.gouv.fr](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/barometre-des-resultats-de-laction-publique/) : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/barometre-des-resultats-de-laction-publique/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/barometre-des-resultats-de-laction-publique/).

Local state officials use the barometer every day to keep track on the evolution of the indicators in a specific territory, to define whether or not actions and policies need to be adapted. Providing a unique tool for 101 departments and 18 regions considerably increased the efficiency of governmental action at the local level. Civil society can also check the barometer and use the underlying open data to carry out analyses of the Government’s policies, as it has been done by the Terra Nova think thank : [https://tnova.fr/notes/barometre-des-resultats-de-l-action-publique-la-france-de-la-fibre-optique](https://tnova.fr/notes/barometre-des-resultats-de-l-action-publique-la-france-de-la-fibre-optique) [https://tnova.fr/notes/barometre-des-resultats-de-l-action-publique-france-services-des-lieux-au-service-du-public-dans-les-territoires](https://tnova.fr/notes/barometre-des-resultats-de-l-action-publique-france-services-des-lieux-au-service-du-public-dans-les-territoires)

**Use case 3 : Energy transition public policy**

Open data on energy provided by energy network operators are used by local authorities to get a better knowledge of renewable energy production in their territory. This diagnosis allows them to plan policies aiming at ensuring an adequate transition towards renewables. Here is an example of such use and impact : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/EnR_PdlL/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/EnR_PdlL/). In this example, open data on electricity production, electricity and gas consumption, biomethane production and other open data provided by energy network operations (Enedis, GRDF, GRTgaz, RTE) are consolidated into dashboards on renewable energy production.

The votes and amendments of the Parliament’s two chambers are available on their respective open data portals : [http://data.assemblee-nationale.fr/](http://data.assemblee-nationale.fr/) ; [http://data.senat.fr/](http://data.senat.fr/). This open data use, namely by the civil society initiative « Regards Citoyens » that built websites such as as [www.nosdeputes.fr](http://www.nosdeputes.fr/) and [www.nossenateurs.fr](http://www.nossenateurs.fr/), improves citizens’ information on the global participation of their MPs, thus impacting their upcoming votes.

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on decision-making processes (i.e. are public administrations making use of the data as evidence to be included in their daily operations)?

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several high impact use cases illustrate the impact of open data on decision-making processes. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Deciding on which companies to dedicate support and aid**

Open data on French companies has been used to design Signaux Faibles, a digital service that helps public officials target state support measures on companies in difficulty. Indeed, businesses difficulties are often discovered too late, when many public aids that could have enabled them to rebound are no longer actionable or less effective. The tool relies on the infrastructure of the SIRENE database of companies and their establishments, available in open data and allows to identify companies in difficulty as early as possible. It then becomes possible to support them early and thus participate in the prevention of failures ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/signaux_faibles/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/signaux_faibles/))

**Use case 2 : Make better informed decisions to foster inclusion in employment**

The Operational Directory of Occupations and Jobs (ROME), published as open data ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/repertoire-operationnel-des-metiers-et-des-emplois-rome/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/repertoire-operationnel-des-metiers-et-des-emplois-rome/)) is used by the digital service « Le pilotage de l’inclusion » ([https://pilotage.inclusion.beta.gouv.fr/)](https://pilotage.inclusion.beta.gouv.fr/)) to provide dashboards allowing all inclusion stakeholders to make better informed decisions on which people to provide socio-professional support to, while reducing the time for collecting data and producing indicators.

**Use case 3 : Fiche commune entreprises**

A lot of public officials intervening in businesses need information on companies, namely on the controls that have been carried out or on the aid already granted, but this information is not always well shared within the administration. Open data is used to build a tool, Fiche Commune Entreprise, that provides public officials with consolidated information on companies for them to have a global vision of the relations between the administration and the company and decide the most relevant action to implement : [https://fce.fabrique.social.gouv.fr/](https://fce.fabrique.social.gouv.fr/).

**Use case 1 : Social position indices in French schools (primary school, middle school, high school)** 

Open data on social position indices in French schools (students’ social status based on their parents’ professions and social categories) is used to understand and analyse schools’ social mixing and better think public policies to promote social diversity : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/cartographie-de-lindice-de-position-sociale-des-ecoles-et-colleges-france-metropolitaine-et-drom/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/cartographie-de-lindice-de-position-sociale-des-ecoles-et-colleges-france-metropolitaine-et-drom/) 

**Use case 2 : AccesLibre**

AccesLibre ([https://acceslibre.beta.gouv.fr/)](https://acceslibre.beta.gouv.fr/)) publishes in open data a dataset on the accessibility of establishments open to the public (aggregated from various accessibility stakeholders) : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/acceslibre/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/acceslibre/). It uses this data to power a platform that enables all users, including people with disabilities, to have access to the information they need to know whether they can access a specific establishment. Data from all main welfare providers gathered by the open source project OpenFisca [https://openfisca.org/](https://openfisca.org/) is used by the portal mesdroitssociaux.gouv.fr (« my social rights ») to allow citizens to view the welfare entitlements they can access to (e.g. housing benefits, back-to-work incentives, etc.), stimulate the amount of such benefits and carry out online administrative procedures to get them. **Use case 4 : Helping refugees in their administrative procedures**

The Interministerial Delegation for the Reception and Integration of Refugees (DIAIR) developed a multilingual platform to spread relevant information to help refugees in France. The [refugies.info](http://refugies.info/) platform allows to list and translate in a collaborative way the support systems and administrative procedures dedicated to the integration of refugees in France. Question:

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.

The COVID-19 crisis helped shed light on the importance of opening health related data (especially public health) to the public.

Several high impact use cases illustrate the impact of open data on society’s awareness on health and wellbeing related issues. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Data on pathologies**

The National Health Insurance opened a set of data on some fifty pathologies, chronic treatments and episodes of care : diabetes, acute coronary syndrome, heart failure, acute stroke, breast cancer, lung cancer, Parkinson’s disease, epilepsy, cystic fibrosis, anxiety treatments, maternity, etc. What are the numbers of patients treated for these different diseases ? How is the prevalence changing ? How is the number of patients distributed throughout France ? What is the reimbursed expenditure allocated to each of the diseases identified ? Data and associated visualisations allow every citizen to be better informed on those questions : [https://data.ameli.fr/pages/data-pathologies/](https://data.ameli.fr/pages/data-pathologies/).

**Use case 2 : Medication Data**

Several datasets on medicine prescriptions and usage ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/open-medic-base-complete-sur-les-depenses-de-medicaments-interregimes/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/open-medic-base-complete-sur-les-depenses-de-medicaments-interregimes/) [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/medicaments-rembourses-par-lassurance-maladie/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/medicaments-rembourses-par-lassurance-maladie/) [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/open-phmev-bases-sur-les-prescriptions-hospitalieres-de-medicaments-delivrees-en-ville/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/open-phmev-bases-sur-les-prescriptions-hospitalieres-de-medicaments-delivrees-en-ville/)) have been used to provide citizens with information on the usage of medication and the associated expenditures : [https://www.spallian.com/2022/05/02/consommation-medicaments-openmedic/](https://www.spallian.com/2022/05/02/consommation-medicaments-openmedic/) or [https://open-snds.has-sante.fr/](https://open-snds.has-sante.fr/).

Open data on medication is also used in the service [https://data.ansm.sante.fr/](https://data.ansm.sante.fr/) that provides every citizen with quick and understandable information and statistics about medication. It namely allows them to know about the history of adverse drug reaction reports, medication errors and drug stock outs.

**Use case 3 : Recosanté**

Open data on air quality and pollution is used to power a digital public service called Recosanté [https://recosante.beta.gouv.fr/](https://recosante.beta.gouv.fr/) that provides information on air quality through a newsletter and advice on how to protect one self from the health impacts of air pollution.

**Use case 4 : Yuka**

Open data on food products (ingredients, nutritional information, labels, etc.) power services such as Yuka, that provides people with clear information on one product’s impact on health : [https://yuka.io/](https://yuka.io/).

**Use case 5 : Public health data**

Open data on public health has been made easily accessible through a portal developed by Santé publique France itself (the national public health agency) namely through visualisations and hundreds of indicators on public health. It allows citizens to get quickly informed : [https://geodes.santepubliquefrance.fr/](https://geodes.santepubliquefrance.fr/).

Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on the level of employment? 

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several use cases illustrate the impact of open data on the level of employment. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Determine one’s career orientation**

The Operational Directory of Occupatins and Jobs, available in open data, data on the labor market and data on job offers, available in open data, are used to build a service that allows young people to actively build their career orientation by discovering skills, interests and job opportunities : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/diagoriente/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/diagoriente/)

**Use case 2 : Look for a job**

Open data on the labour market and on job offers are used to power the service La Bonne Boîte [https://labonneboite.pole-emploi.fr](https://labonneboite.pole-emploi.fr/), a tool that facilitates job search through algorithmic predictions uncovering the hidden job market (which represents 75% of job opportunities).

**Use case 3 : Find relevant training**

Open data on the labour market and employment is used to nurture La Bonne Formation, [https://beta.gouv.fr/startups/la-bonne-formation.html](https://beta.gouv.fr/startups/la-bonne-formation.html), a service that helps people find relevant training to be able to return to work, and find out about possible financing.

**Use case 4 : Get a diploma or a professional certification**

The Operational Directory of Occupations and Jobs, available in open data is used to power a service called Avril that allows people to obtain a diploma from their professional skills : [https://avril.pole-emploi.fr/](https://avril.pole-emploi.fr/).

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on the level of innovation and the adoption of new technologies? 

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several use cases illustrate the impact of open data on the level of innovation and the adoption of new technologies. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results.

**Use case 1 : Help beekeepers leverage new technologies to estimate floral resources around hives**

Open data on agricultural parcels, organic farming plots, land use, forest areas, etc. is used to offer beekepers a service that allow them to simply analyse resources available around different apiaries so as to make better informed decisions : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/beegis/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/beegis/).

**Use case 2 : Open data for machine learning**

Open data also fosters the creation of new innovative services based on machine learning. A catalogue ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/donnees-machine-learning/)](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/donnees-machine-learning/)) has been created to reference open datasets considered as usable by machine learning algorithms.

**Use case 3 : Open data for smarter cities**

Open data has been identified as key in the strategy for smarter cities in France :

[https://www.entreprises.gouv.fr/files/files/en-pratique/etudes-et-statistiques/dossiers-de -the-DGE/rapport_de_la_smart_city_a_la_realite_des_territoires_connectes.pdf](https://www.entreprises.gouv.fr/files/files/en-pratique/etudes-et-statistiques/dossiers-de%20-the-DGE/rapport_de_la_smart_city_a_la_realite_des_territoires_connectes.pdf)

. Use cases identified in this report cover waste, transportation, energy management, etc. (i.e. innovative solutions for energy optimisation such as smart grids :

[https://www.edf.fr/collectivites/le-mag/le-mag-collectivites/strategie-energetique-territoriale/open-data-et-smart-city-au-service-des-economies-d-energie](https://www.edf.fr/collectivites/le-mag/le-mag-collectivites/strategie-energetique-territoriale/open-data-et-smart-city-au-service-des-economies-d-energie)

Question:
Is the use of open data in your country having an impact on the level of entrepreneurship (especially of women and minorities) and business creation (especially with Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises)? 

For justification:
* If yes, please explain how and what kind of impact is created on the topic and provide examples of maximum 3 recent open data reuse cases in the form of research or application, whether developed by government or by civil society.
Justification:
Several use cases illustrate the impact of open data on the level of entrepreneurship and business creation. These use cases have been researched and followed throughout the time, to keep on measuring their results. Open business-related data has become a key ressource for new companies and overall lower the cost of entry in the market for new entrepreneurs.

**Use case 1 : A service to help entrepreneurs in their administrative procedures**

Open business data is used by the service Annuaire des Entreprises [https://annuaire-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/](https://annuaire-entreprises.data.gouv.fr/) through which entrepreneurs can quickly retrieve their information and thus carry out their administrative procedures more easily (SIREN/SIRET, NAF/APE code, VAT number, etc.) : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/annuaire-des-entreprises/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/pages/onboarding/annuaire-des-entreprises/).

Open business data also feeds the service [https://mon-entreprise.urssaf.fr/](https://mon-entreprise.urssaf.fr/) that provides simulators, calculators and tools to help entrepreneurs in launching their project/activity.

**Use case 2 : Place des entreprises**

Open business data is used to power a digital public service, Place des entreprises, that connects small sized and medium sized enterprises with the right contact person within the administration for personalised help and advice (human resources, labour law, financial difficulties, investment, commercial development, etc.) to help them develop their activity : [https://place-des-entreprises.beta.gouv.fr/](https://place-des-entreprises.beta.gouv.fr/).

**Use case 3 : Emphasize gender inequalities**

Open data is used in analyses shedding light on gender inequalities and, by doing so, might be contributing to its decrease. For example, the professional equality index, designed to advance equal pay between women and men within companies, was published in open data ([https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/index-egalite-professionnelle-f-h-des-entreprises-de-plus-de-250-salaries/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/index-egalite-professionnelle-f-h-des-entreprises-de-plus-de-250-salaries/)). It allowed for reuses that help its understanding, such as this interactive computer graphics to understand and analyse the professional equality index : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/index-degalite-professionnelle-modalites-analyses-et-cartographie/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/index-degalite-professionnelle-modalites-analyses-et-cartographie/).

Question:

For justification:

Justification:
A discussion module is available for users for each dataset. They can express their opinion on the published dataset, whether it is positive or negative. This discussion module also makes it possible to report anomalies or areas for improvement to the producer.

We believe that this evaluation mechanism provides more qualitative information than a simple five-star mechanism. Indeed, a five-star mechanism does not provide information on the improvement prospects.  See example : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/base-sirene-des-entreprises-et-de-leurs-etablissements-siren-siret/#/discussions](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/base-sirene-des-entreprises-et-de-leurs-etablissements-siren-siret/#/discussions)

It is also possible to "follow" a dataset, which can be an indicator of popularity.
Guide to Answering: Such mechanism could be a star rating system or similar voting/rating mechanism.
Reviewer 2 Comments: Given that the availability of a discussion forum is asked in Q71 and feedback at the dataset level in Q66b, we do not consider the discussion module as a mechanism to rate quality. For this question, we are interested in a feature that gives a clear summary of data quality as rated by portal users (such as the number of "likes" a start rating etc).

On top of that, the team is always working on the curation of the datasets on the portal and do their best to prevent inappropriate content (publicity mainly).

- the "highlight" button for the platform administrator allows to bring up a data set in the ranking

Justification:
When the Etalab mission was created and the government launched the “Open data” policy in 2011, an [open license](https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/ETALAB-Licence-Ouverte-v2.0.pdf)  was developed to make it easier for re-users to understand their rights and obligations.

This license began to be widely used by the majority of administrations. However, some of them used specific licenses.

Faced with the profusion of licenses, the content of which was sometimes very heterogeneous and could harm cross-referencing of data sets, the [law for a digital republic](https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichLoiPubliee.do?idDocument=JORFDOLE000031589829&type=general&legislature=14) intervened to limit the choice of licenses to which administrations could resort.

When the administrations need to choose a license for the free re-use of their public information, be it data or software, they will have to choose it among the licenses appearing in the decree provided for in article [L. 323-2 of CRPA](https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do?idArticle=LEGIARTI000034504991&cidTexte=LEGITEXT000031366350&dateTexte=29991231).

When no license provided for in the decree meets the needs of an administration and that it wishes to use a specific license, this license must be approved by the State, in this case the DINUM, according to the criteria set by the decree.

- A documentation is available to support producers on how to publish data sets in machine readable format: [here](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/data.gouv.fr/) and [here](https://doc.data.gouv.fr/a-propos/que-publier-et-comment-le-publier/)
- The Etalab team launched in 2019 [www.schema.data.gouv.fr](http://www.schema.data.gouv.fr/) a referencing and support service for the creation of public data schemas for France. From schema.data.gouv.fr and the tools attached to it, it is possible to consult the referenced data schema, to validate that a data set conforms to a schema, to generate documentation and sample data sets automatically or suggest standardized entry forms. Any actor is also free to propose the referencing of diagrams on schema.data.gouv.fr.
- Etalab supports the [Validata](https://validata.etalab.studio/) project, whose partners are Open Data France, Jailbreak, La fing and Datactivist. - Etalab provides since january a tool [publier.etalab.studio](http://publier.etalab.studio) to help users to generate their data in a structured way. This tool helps to get better quality on data published on french open data platform.
- Good practices are highlighted on [data.gouv.fr homepage](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/) (“Jeux de données à la une”). These datasets are also communicated to producers wishing to publish quality datasets in a machine-readable format.
- We publish an [article every month](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/suivi-des-sorties-mai-2020/) to showcase the most important publications and highlight good practices by producers.
- Any producer who wishes to publish a dataset (whether he is internal or external to the administration) has the possibility to contact Etalab team in order to obtain assistance in the publication of his data: creation of data schema, assistance in choosing the format, assistance in improving data quality, assistance in the editorialization and documentation of datasets, assistance in publishing data on data.gouv.fr.
Guide to Answering: By ‘regularly’ we mean a bi-annual or at least annual frequency for activities such as e-learning modules and materials, webinars, meetings. Incentivisation can include the promotion of good quality datasets, e.g. featuring them on the portal homepage, showcasing the publishers as best practices at data providers’ events. Assistance can be provided through formal processes (e.g. data audits), training sessions with data providers, other training and/or awareness raising activities (‘roadshows’) etc.

Is there a national extension of the DCAT-AP standard developed for your country? 

For justification:
* If yes, please (1) briefly outline the reasons for this decision, and (2) what the main differences between the national variation and the EU standard are.
* If applicable, please provide the URL to the documentation of the national DCAT-AP extension.
Justification:
France has built a specification of the data model for catalog of datasets published in open data by local authorities. 
The opendata catalog of a community gathers the metadata description of the datasets it publishes. It can be generated automatically by the platform that hosts or harvests them. Several standards allow the standardization of the metadata of a catalog (INSPIRE for geographic data, DCAT and its variations for all types of open data), but local catalogs, when they exist, whether they are exposed via an API or extracted in the form of files, often depend on the technical capacity of the solution used and its configuration (different formats, more or less rich or extensive, depending on the platform, unique catalog and not for each producer when the platform is shared, distinction or not between datasets and resources, etc). Not to mention that many local authorities use simple websites to make their data available.

The specification of a simplified data model should make it possible to harmonize these local catalogs in a format accessible to all local authorities and facilitate their consolidation in a national inventory, the "catalog of open local data catalogs".

[https://schema.data.gouv.fr/scdl/catalogue/0.1.2/](https://schema.data.gouv.fr/scdl/catalogue/0.1.2/)

Question:
Do you use a model (such as the 5-Star Open Data or FAIR) to assess the quality of deployment of data in your country?

For justification:
* If yes, please briefly describe.
Justification:
A discussion module is available for users for each dataset. They can express their opinion on the published dataset, whether it is positive or negative. This discussion module also makes it possible to report anomalies or areas for improvement to the producer. This evaluation mechanism thus provides more qualitative information than a simple five-star mechanism. Indeed, a five-star mechanism does not provide information on the improvement prospects.

[See example](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/base-sirene-des-entreprises-et-de-leurs-etablissements-siren-siret/)

However it is very usefull for both data producers et data reusers to be able to attest quickly a dataset’s quality. To this end we developed a metadata quality score for dataset : [https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/un-nouveau-score-de-qualite-des-metadonnees-sur-les-jeux-de-donnees/](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/un-nouveau-score-de-qualite-des-metadonnees-sur-les-jeux-de-donnees/)
Guide to Answering: For more information, please visit: http://5stardata.info/en/ or https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/inline-files/W3C04.pdf.

Question:
Do you conduct activities to promote and familiarise data providers with ways to ensure higher quality data (such as promoting the model referenced in the previous question)?

For justification:
* If yes, please briefly describe.
Justification:
We developed a strategy on dataset quality inspired from the 5-star model :

**Licence** :

We developed our [own licence](https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/ETALAB-Licence-Ouverte-v2.0.pdf) and provide [guidelines](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/licences) and guides on how to choose a licence and why (see previous questions).

**Reusability** :

With our focus on data literacy and the organisation of events, we foster the reusability of data by insisting notably on [quality of documentation](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/qualite/documenter-les-donnees/) of data, [description of metadata](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/qualite/documenter-les-donnees/#description-des-metadonnees) and how [reuses are important](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/juridique/reutilisation/#qu-est-ce-qu-une-reutilisation) for example (see dimension 1 for more insight).

Reuses are highlighted in the same way as data [on the portal](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/reuses/covid-19-en-france-au-06-juillet-2020-surveillance-des-entrees-hospitalieres-et-des-tests-de-depistage/) and through our [communication](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/).

**Machine readability and openness** :

A documentation is available to support producers on how to publish data sets in machine readable format: [here](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/data.gouv.fr/) and [here](https://doc.data.gouv.fr/a-propos/que-publier-et-comment-le-publier/).

On top of advocacy programs and [editorial content](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/posts/) we develop tools to help producers to provide high quality data. For instance,

- The Etalab team launched in 2019 [www.schema.data.gouv.fr](http://www.schema.data.gouv.fr/) a referencing, validation and support service for the creation of public data schemas for France. From schema.data.gouv.fr and the tools attached to it, it is possible to consult the referenced data schema, to validate that a data set conforms to a schema, to generate documentation and sample data sets automatically or suggest standardized entry forms. Any actor is also free to propose the referencing of diagrams on schema.data.gouv.fr.
- Etalab has also developed a tool, [CSV-GG](https://csv-gg.etalab.studio/), that helps you create a CSV file that conforms to an existing data schema. The tool guides you through several steps to obtain a complete, valid and structured file.

**Open identifier**

Discoverability of data.gouv.fr catalog is one of our top priorities. With this in mind a lot of effort are put in the  improvement of the search engine, for example:

- the tag system of the datasets makes it possible to optimize the search
- the "highlight" button for the platform administrator allows to bring up a data set in the ranking

**Linked-data**

We wrote a [quality guide](https://guides.etalab.gouv.fr/qualite/preparer-le-jeu-de-donnees/#la-structure-du-jeu-de-donnees) to help administration in the open data strategy. This guide underlines the necessity to include “linked data” (données pivot) that facilitates the crossover between datasets. Ex. Identification number of a company, geolocalisation etc.

We are also working on a tool enabling the enrichment of resources with additional third party data available on the portal

The platform data.gouv.fr allows users to link a specific resource to a common standard / schema shared by the community. This feature allow users to access easily to all the resources depending of this specific schema.

Question: Of the percentage indicated in the previous question (Q128c), what percentage of datasets also consistely use Uniform Resource Identifiers?

An identifier may be the object’s name (e.g. city name ‘Luxembourg’, or ‘10717’ -- a Berlin postcode), or a word describing the object (‘population’; ‘gender’), or another arbitrary identifier such as ‘XYZ0’, an identifier that makes sense only in the context of that dataset. Choosing identifiers based on known standards should be the common practice though, to facilitate data integration and linked data.

Question:
Do you monitor the improvements in terms of quality of open data deployment?

For justification:
* If yes, please briefly describe how.
Justification:
We track the progression of our metadata quality score. 

On top of that, each new datasets are monitored in our internal team and we can check for each one if correction needs to be done.
